item.title: 10 diet types you must adopt in 2025 for a healthy heart - The Times of India
item.description:
10 Diet Types You Must Adopt in 2025 for a Healthy Heart

Publication Date: Dec 31, 2024 | Source: TimesOfIndia.com

As we approach 2025, adopting heart-friendly diets will be crucial for maintaining cardiovascular health, reducing inflammation, lowering cholesterol, and promoting longevity.

  • Mediterranean diet: Reduces heart disease risk by promoting healthy cholesterol.
  • DASH Diet: Aims to lower blood pressure by focusing on fruits, vegetables, and whole grains.
  • Paleo diet: Emphasizes whole foods like lean meats and fruits while avoiding processed foods.
  • Low-carb, high-fiber diet: Helps keep blood sugar low and reduces heart disease risk.
  • Flexitarian diet: Primarily plant-based but allows occasional meat consumption.
  • Anti-inflammatory diet: Incorporates foods that reduce chronic inflammation.
  • Low-sodium diet: Focuses on fresh foods and limits high-sodium processed products.
  • Whole-food, plant-based diet: Focuses on whole foods while eliminating processed options.
  • Plant-based diet: Rich in fiber and antioxidants, protecting heart health.
  • Intermittent fasting: May lower blood pressure and cholesterol through a pattern of eating.
“These diets reduce inflammation, decrease cholesterol, and usually preserve the functionality of the heart.”

Adopting these diets in 2025 could significantly enhance heart health and overall well-being.

item.title: 5 warning signs of Vitamin B12 deficiency in your feet you shouldn't ignore - The Times of India
item.description:
5 Warning Signs of Vitamin B12 Deficiency in Your Feet

Publication Date: [Date not provided] Source: Times of India

The symptoms of Vitamin B12 deficiency can lead to nerve damage and affect daily life. It's essential to recognize early signs to prevent irreversible damage.

  • Numbness and tingling in feet
  • Burning sensation in extremities
  • Difficulty walking or loss of balance
  • Pale or yellowish skin on feet
  • Persistent cold feet
“According to the National Institutes of Health (NIH), peripheral neuropathy caused by B12 deficiency can become irreversible if untreated.”

Recognizing these signs early can help in addressing Vitamin B12 deficiency and maintaining overall nerve health.

item.title: 5 Reasons Why Coffee Can Help You Live Longer, According to Science - EatingWell
item.description:
5 Reasons Why Coffee Can Help You Live Longer, According to Science

Publication Date: Not specified Source: Not specified

Many people wish to live long and healthy lives. While the fountain of youth has yet to be found, certain dietary and lifestyle choices can help keep your ticker ticking and your body working for a long time. Among these choices, coffee consumption has shown significant health benefits that may contribute to longevity.

  • May Help Manage a Healthy Weight: Caffeine intake can promote reductions in body fat and weight.
  • May Support Heart Health: Drinking 3 to 5 cups of coffee per day may reduce the risk of heart disease by 15%.
  • May Reduce Risk of Type 2 Diabetes: Coffee drinking is linked to a lower risk of developing type 2 diabetes.
  • May Help Protect from Certain Cancers: Coffee may reduce the risk of liver and endometrial cancers.
  • May Improve Cognitive Function and Mood: Caffeine has been shown to enhance cognitive function and may lower the risk of depression.
“Who doesn't want to live a long and healthy life? While there is no guarantee, there are some things you can do that may help keep that inevitable occurrence from happening too soon.”

The evidence suggests that moderate coffee consumption can provide several health benefits, potentially helping to prolong life.

item.title: As Ozempic takes over weight loss conversation in 2024, find out what the New Year may bring for its development and accessibility - The Indian Express
item.description:
As Ozempic takes over weight loss conversation in 2024, find out what the New Year may bring for its development and accessibility

Publication Date: 2024

Source: Indian Express

The article discusses the growing popularity of Ozempic and other GLP-1 receptor agonists as weight loss solutions in 2024. Originally intended for diabetes management, they have sparked debates about ethics, accessibility, and long-term health effects.

  • Ozempic has gained traction for effective weight loss, showing a 15–20% reduction compared to lifestyle changes.
  • Key factors for normalization include celebrity endorsements and increased public awareness.
  • Concerns about high costs and accessibility are highlighted, with potential solutions suggested.
  • Health risks associated with long-term use include gastrointestinal issues and pancreatitis.
“While GLP-1 agonists offer a promising solution for weight loss, their long-term effects, accessibility, and ethical use require careful regulation.” - Dr. Jagadish Hiremath

The article concludes that while GLP-1 agonists like Ozempic present new opportunities for weight management, careful consideration of their implications and accessibility will be essential moving forward.

item.title: CDC on High Alert as Bird Flu Cases Rise in the US: Is the H5N1 Virus Showing Pandemic Red Flags? - The Economic Times
item.description:
CDC on High Alert as Bird Flu Cases Rise in the US: Is the H5N1 Virus Showing Pandemic Red Flags?

Last Updated: 31 December, 2024 09:59 AM GMT
Source: The Feed

Bird flu cases are on the rise in the U.S., and the CDC is on high alert. With 66 confirmed human cases so far, officials are watching closely for signs that the virus could mutate and spread more easily between people, raising concerns about a potential pandemic.

  • The CDC is monitoring an increase in bird flu cases, especially the H5N1 strain.
  • 66 confirmed human cases have been reported.
  • CDC is looking for signs of potential mutations and human transmission.
  • A patient in Louisiana was hospitalized with a mutated virus.
  • Public risk remains low, with no transmission from the Louisiana patient reported.
A spokesperson from the CDC mentioned, "We are looking for clusters of influenza A(H5N1) human cases, which could indicate that the virus is better able to spread."

The CDC will continue to monitor the situation and provide updates to prevent the spread of the virus.

item.title: How to Detox After a Night of Partying: Quick Tips for Recovery - HerZindagi
item.description:
How to Detox After a Night of Partying: Quick Tips for Recovery

Published on: [Insert Publication Date] by HerZindagi

Partying can be fun but can also take a toll on your body. After a night out, it's essential to detox and help your body recover. Here are some quick tips to bounce back quickly and feel rejuvenated.

  • Hydrate well: Drink plenty of fluids to flush out toxins.
  • Nutritious breakfast: Start your day with fruits high in vitamins and antioxidants.
  • Detox teas: Ginger, lemon, or green tea can aid digestion and help with detox.
  • Sleep and rest: Allow your body time to heal by taking naps or getting extra sleep.
  • Avoid caffeine: Too much caffeine can dehydrate; opt for water or detox tea.
“Detoxing is essential after a night of partying to restore balance and energy.”

Take these steps to help your body recover after a night of celebration and enjoy a healthier lifestyle.

item.title: Microplastic Concentrations In The Human Body Linked To Multiple Tissue Lesions - IFLScience
item.description:
Microplastic Concentrations in the Human Body Linked to Multiple Tissue Lesions

Publication Date: October 2023 Source: IFLScience

A new metadata analysis into the presence of microplastic concentrations in humans has highlighted multiple links with tissue damage and other health conditions.

  • Microplastics have been detected in multiple human systems including respiratory, digestive, and reproductive organs.
  • Inhalation is identified as the primary route for MNP entry into the body.
  • Children and elderly individuals are identified as being more susceptible to MNP exposure.
  • MNPs are suggested to cause various health issues including oxidative stress and potential neurodegenerative diseases.
  • Notable correlations exist between MNP concentrations and diseases such as cancer and inflammatory bowel disease.
“MNPs with different types, shapes and sizes have been detected in various human systems. Notably, the occurrence of MNPs is markedly correlated with corresponding lesions and diseases, which is the key evidence that MNPs harm human health.”

The findings highlight the urgent need for more research into the characterization and effects of microplastics in human health.

item.title: GMC Anantnag creates history, performs 50 LBB-A Pacing procedures under C-arm - Greater Kashmir
item.description:
GMC Anantnag creates history, performs 50 LBB-A Pacing procedures under C-arm

Date: December 31, 2024 | Source: Greater Kashmir

Government Medical College (GMC) Anantnag has successfully performed 50 cases of Left Bundle Branch Area (LBB-A) pacing under C-arm in just four months, marking a significant achievement in cardiac care without electrophysiology (EP) backup.

  • The achievement was led by Principal GMC Anantnag, Professor. Dr. Rukhsana Najeeb, and a dedicated cardiology team.
  • Initially started in September 2024, this innovative procedure transitions from conventional pacemaker implantation.
  • The success rate of the procedures reached 95%, with no reported mortality.
“This shows innovation, perseverance, and commitment to advancing cardiac care in a resource-constrained setting,” said Dr. Najeeb.
“Dr. Najeeb congratulated the cardiology team on this historic accomplishment and reiterated her commitment to elevating GMC Anantnag to one of the top medical institutions in the country.”

item.title: Shortage of hepatitis B vaccine continues to plague Kerala’s private hospitals - The Hindu
item.description:
Shortage of Hepatitis B Vaccine Continues to Plague Kerala’s Private Hospitals

Published Date: December 31, 2024
Source: IST

Private hospitals in Kerala are facing an alarming shortage of hepatitis B vaccines, affecting both new staff and at-risk patients.

  • The hepatitis B virus is transmitted during birth and through contact with infected blood or fluids.
  • Patients undergoing dialysis are at an extremely high risk and require vaccination for protection.
  • Unvaccinated individuals exposed to the virus need hepatitis B immunoglobulin treatment, which can be expensive.
  • Newborns of infected mothers and newly recruited healthcare staff are severely impacted.
  • The vaccine supply is expected to improve, but delays persist, leaving hospitals struggling.
  • Manufacturers have reduced production due to low profit margins and reported shortages of raw materials.
  • Bivalent vaccines, such as twinrix, are available, providing combined protection against hepatitis A and B.
  • Public health experts emphasize the need for more vaccine options amid frequent hepatitis A outbreaks in the state.
“If Indian manufacturers can come up with a cost-effective bivalent vaccine, the people will be protected from two hepatitis viruses for life.”

The ongoing shortage of the hepatitis B vaccine poses serious health risks, urging for immediate attention from manufacturers and health authorities.

item.title: Woman who lost 20 kilos, shares 8 effective tips for weight loss: ‘Chew everything thoroughly’ - Hindustan Times
item.description:
Woman Shares 8 Effective Tips for Weight Loss After Losing 20 Kilos

Dec 31, 2024 by Zarafshan Shiraz

Pritika Srinivasan, a CA and nutritionist, shares her personal journey of losing 20 kilos, emphasizing that weight loss is about health and confidence, not just numbers on a scale. She highlights eight practical strategies that helped her achieve her weight loss goals.

  • 1. Walk up and down the stairs for 10 minutes daily.
  • 2. Don't eat extra when you are full; practice mindfulness to avoid binge eating.
  • 3. Say NO to sugar to prevent health issues.
  • 4. Eat home-made food to control ingredients and avoid hidden calories.
  • 5. Stop eating oily and junk food that increase health risks.
  • 6. Include more protein in your diet for satiety and muscle support.
  • 7. Aim for at least 30 minutes of moderate physical activity every day.
  • 8. Chew everything thoroughly to promote better eating habits.
“Protein and fiber help you feel fuller for longer, reducing the chances of overeating or making unhealthy food choices,” said Dr Pramod Tripathi.

These strategies are not only effective for weight loss but also promote overall health and well-being. Always consult with a healthcare professional for personalized advice.

item.title: World News | ⚡Health Alert Issued Over Deadly Mosquito-Borne Virus in Southeast Australia - LatestLY
item.description:
Health Alert Issued Over Deadly Mosquito-Borne Virus in Southeast Australia

Publication Date: Tuesday

Source: Victoria Health Authorities

Health authorities in Victoria, Australia's second-most populous state, have issued a high-risk warning after identifying a human case of a deadly mosquito-borne virus.

  • High-risk warning has been issued in Victoria.
  • A human case of a deadly mosquito-borne virus has been identified.
  • This alert comes amidst concerns over health safety due to vector-borne diseases.
“High-risk warning issued by health authorities.”

Authorities urge residents to take precautions against mosquito bites.

item.title: Norovirus cases rising in the US: How it spreads, what precautions can be taken - The Indian Express
item.description:
Norovirus cases rising in the US: How it spreads, what precautions can be taken

Publication Date: December 2023 | Source: The New York Times

The stomach infection norovirus is causing concern in the United States, with over 90 cases reported in the first week of December, primarily linked to raw oysters.

  • At least 80 people became ill after consuming contaminated raw oysters from a restaurant event in Los Angeles.
  • These oysters were sourced from British Columbia and had been distributed across 14 US states before recall.
  • Norovirus is highly contagious and spreads through contaminated food, water, and surfaces.
  • Symptoms include vomiting, diarrhea, nausea, and abdominal pain, with severe cases leading to dehydration.
  • Precautions include frequent handwashing and cleaning surfaces with hypochlorite solutions to prevent spread.
  • The illness is self-limiting, typically lasting two to three days without vaccines available.
“Norovirus infection is associated with intestinal inflammation, malnutrition and may cause long-term morbidity.” - WHO

The rise in norovirus cases poses a serious public health concern, necessitating awareness and strict hygiene practices to curb its spread.

item.title: Health alert issued over deadly mosquito-borne virus in southeast Australia - Social News XYZ
item.description:
Health Alert Issued Over Deadly Mosquito-Borne Virus in Southeast Australia

Date: December 31, 2024

Source: Social News XYZ

Health authorities in Victoria, Australia, have issued a warning following the identification of a human case of the Japanese encephalitis (JE) virus.

  • First human case of JE virus reported in Victoria this summer.
  • Health officials advise precautions against mosquito bites.
  • The JE virus can lead to severe illness, including brain infections.
  • Children and the elderly are at higher risk of severe illness.
"The risk of mosquito-borne diseases remains high in the coming weeks. Taking measures to avoid mosquito bites is critical to protect against infections." - Christian McGrath, Acting Chief Health Officer

This health alert underscores the importance of public awareness and preventive measures as Australia enters the mosquito season.

item.title: Start 2025 Right: Simple Detox Tips After New Year's Eve Celebrations - NDTV Food
item.description:
Start 2025 Right: Simple Detox Tips After New Year's Eve Celebrations

Publication Date: January 1, 2025 Source: NDTV Food

Introduction

As we celebrate the arrival of 2025, many of us may feel the effects of overindulgence during New Year's celebrations. A gentle detox can help reset the body and mind for the year ahead.

Key Points

  • Hydrate with warm lemon water to kickstart digestion and boost hydration.
  • Re-evaluate your diet by including nutrient-rich foods like fruits and vegetables.
  • Cut back on alcohol to support the liver's detoxification efforts.
  • Exercise regularly to promote toxin release through sweat.
  • Prioritize sleep for recovery and natural detox processes.
  • Be mindful of sugar and salt intake to avoid bloating and fatigue.

Conclusion

By implementing these simple detox practices, you can help your body recover from the festivities and welcome the new year with renewed energy.

item.title: Polio Outbreak Of 2024: A Global Review Of Countries Battling A Resurgence Of The Disease - TheHealthSite
item.description:
Polio Outbreak Of 2024: A Global Review Of Countries Battling A Resurgence Of The Disease

Publication Date: 2024

Source: The Health Site

The year 2024 saw a resurgence of the polio virus in many countries, affecting both sewage and water systems as well as human populations. This article reviews the countries impacted by this outbreak.

Key Points

  • Pakistan: Three cases of wild poliovirus (WPV1) reported along with environmental samples.
  • Afghanistan: Five WPV1 cases reported alongside multiple positive environmental samples.
  • Nigeria: Notable concern with 30 cases of circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus type 2 (cVDPV2).
  • Angola, Benin, Guinea: Each recorded one case of cVDPV2.
  • Indonesia: At least four cases of cVDPV2 confirmed.
  • Kenya: Detected one positive environmental sample for cVDPV2.
  • Niger: Confirmed one case of cVDPV2 and two positive environmental samples.
  • Somalia: Recorded two positive environmental samples for cVDPV2.
  • Gaza Strip: A new case of variant polio virus reported in a 10-month-old baby, leading to a vaccination drive by the UN.

Symptoms Of Polio

Symptoms of polio can be mild or severe, with some cases leading to paralysis or respiratory failure, highlighting the seriousness of the virus.

Conclusion

The resurgence of polio in 2024 poses serious public health challenges worldwide, necessitating heightened vigilance and vaccination efforts.

"User reviews indicate significant improvements in energy levels and reduced sugar cravings within weeks."

The GlucoBerry supplement is manufactured in an FDA-inspected and GMP-certified facility, ensuring quality and safety of ingredients used.

item.title: Need A Break From Work Stress? Try These 5 10-Minute Hacks And Feel Good Instantly - HerZindagi English
item.description:
Need A Break From Work Stress? Try These 5 10-Minute Hacks And Feel Good Instantly

Publication Date: Not specified Source: HerZindagi

In today's fast-paced world, workplace stress is increasingly common, with many professionals experiencing mental health challenges. The article provides quick 10-minute mental health hacks to help alleviate stress and improve overall well-being.

  • Mindful breathing: Start your day with 10 minutes of mindful breathing techniques like Anulom-Vilom and Pranayama.
  • Desk yoga: Perform simple stretches at your desk to relieve physical strain.
  • Gratitude journaling: Write down three things you're thankful for to lower stress and boost positivity.
  • 20-20-20 rule: To combat screen fatigue, take breaks every 20 minutes to focus on something 20 feet away for 20 seconds.
  • Ayurvedic brews: Replace coffee breaks with calming herbal teas to combat stress.
Sakshi Shah, Founder of GoodLives, emphasizes, “Small, regular actions can sometimes have a significant impact. Incorporating 10-minute mental health exercises into daily life might have a profound impact on time-pressed Indian professionals.”

These simple practices can significantly enhance mental wellness among busy professionals.

item.title: What Is Vestibular Migraine: Symptoms And Causes - NDTV
item.description:
What Is Vestibular Migraine: Symptoms And Causes

Publication Date: Not specified Source: NDTV

Vestibular migraine is a neurological condition that can cause significant discomfort through symptoms like dizziness and vertigo.

  • Vestibular migraine is characterized by dizziness, vertigo, nausea, vomiting, imbalance, sensitivity to light and sound, and visual changes.
  • Other names include migraine-associated vertigo (MAV) and migraine-related vestibulopathy.
  • It's a common cause of dizziness and vertigo, particularly in children.
  • Episodes can last from minutes to 72 hours and may occur without a headache.
  • The exact cause is unknown, but it's believed to relate to abnormal electrical signals in the brain.
  • Risk factors include a history of migraines, stress, and hormonal changes.
“Episodes can last from minutes to 72 hours and can occur without a headache.”

This article provides insight into vestibular migraine, highlighting its symptoms, causes, and how it affects those who suffer from it.

item.title: Speech in movies growing violent with time, even in non-crime ones: Analysis - The Tribune India
item.description:
Speech in movies growing violent with time, even in non-crime ones: Analysis

Publication Date: October 2023
Source: The Tribune

Recent analysis indicates that the use of violent language in movies has escalated significantly over the past five decades, with characters increasingly using words related to 'murder' and 'killing', even in non-crime genres.

  • The study analyzed over 166,000 English-language films produced between 1970 and 2000.
  • Researchers from The Ohio State University utilized machine learning to assess the usage of 'murder' and 'kill' in dialogues.
  • There's a noticeable trend of increasing violent speech across all genres of movies.
  • Female characters are also using more violent language, despite fewer lines than male characters.
  • Approximately seven percent of the analyzed movies contained 'murderous verbs' in their dialogues.
“This is more evidence that violence is a bigger part of the movies we watch than ever before,” said lead author Babak Fotouhi.

In conclusion, the findings highlight the growing normalization of violent language in cinema, raising concerns about its impact on audiences, particularly vulnerable groups like children.

item.title: Hospital admission after taking hallucinogens triples risk of schizophrenia: study - The Hindu
item.description:
Hospital admission after taking hallucinogens triples risk of schizophrenia: study

Published: December 31, 2024 04:55 pm IST

Source: The Conversation

This article discusses a Canadian study that reveals a significant link between hospital admissions due to hallucinogen use and the subsequent development of schizophrenia spectrum disorder (SSD).

  • The study was retrospective, examining hospital records in Ontario from 2008 to 2021.
  • Over 5,000 individuals visited the emergency department for hallucinogen-related issues; 208 developed SSD.
  • The risk of developing SSD was initially a 21-fold increase, then adjusted to a 3.5-fold increase after considering other factors.
  • Alcohol was found to pose a greater risk, with a 4.7-fold increase for alcohol-related visits.
  • The article contrasts the findings with historical data on cannabis and hallucinogen use and risk of SSD.
  • Despite potential risks, hallucinogens are being studied for their therapeutic applications.
“This study does pose important questions about the use of hallucinogens in the clinic and provides further evidence of the dangers of alcohol abuse.”

This study underscores the importance of understanding the mental health risks associated with hallucinogen use while also highlighting the therapeutic potential of these substances.

item.title: Health expert shares dos and don'ts to combat monkeypox - The Indian Express
item.description:
Health Expert Shares Dos and Don'ts to Combat Monkeypox

Publication Date: Not specified Source: The Indian Express

A health expert outlines necessary precautions to combat the spread of monkeypox, emphasizing how the virus is transmitted and methods of prevention.

  • Respiratory droplets are the main carriers; close contact poses a contamination risk.
  • Isolate suspected patients and avoid contact with their belongings.
  • Seek medical advice for unexplained rashes or symptoms.
  • Aches and pains typical of viral illnesses should be managed with symptomatic treatments like Paracetamol.
  • Avoid self-medication without professional advice.
"Respiratory droplets are the main carriers of the monkeypox virus. So you stand a risk of contamination if the infected is within your breathable range and with whom you have a face-to-face interaction," said Dr Suranjit Chatterjee.

This guidance aims to raise awareness and promote safe practices to manage potential outbreaks of monkeypox.

item.title: Expert-Backed Wellness Habits to Boost Your Mental and Physical Health in 2025 - Times Now
item.description:
Expert-Backed Wellness Habits to Boost Your Mental and Physical Health in 2025

Publication Date: N/A Source: Times Now

This article discusses the importance of incorporating wellness practices into daily life as we move into 2025, providing insights from health professionals on mental and physical health strategies.

  • Wellness is a holistic approach to nurturing body, mind, and spirit.
  • Dr. V.M. Gopal Menon emphasizes practices like Pranayama to enhance stress management and focus.
  • Stretching, mindful eating, and prioritizing mental health are key resolutions for the New Year.
  • Mindfulness practices such as meditation and journaling can foster emotional balance.
  • Wellness should be seen as an enhancement to daily life, not just reactionary to illness.
“With a peaceful mind, everything else in life becomes clearer and more manageable.” - Dr. V.M. Gopal Menon

The article underscores the positive impact of making wellness a priority in our routines for a balanced and vibrant life.

item.title: Trends for 2025: New pathogens lurking - Down To Earth Magazine
item.description:
Trends for 2025: New pathogens lurking

Published on: 31 Dec 2024, 9:51 am

The potential for a new pandemic is looming as the UN warns of emerging zoonotic diseases linked to climate change and human activities. The year 2024 has seen an increase in outbreaks affecting global health security.

  • A report by the UN emphasizes that emerging diseases could trigger a pandemic by 2030, with fatalities projected to rise drastically due to climate change.
  • A virulent form of mpox has led to about 50,000 cases in Africa, prompting a WHO public health emergency.
  • Vector-borne diseases like dengue and chikungunya are experiencing widespread outbreaks in Latin America and Europe.
  • The spread of H5N1 influenza in North America poses risks of mutations as it spreads beyond poultry.
  • The UN announced a declaration to reduce deaths linked to antimicrobial resistance by 10% annually by 2030.
“The scars of the novel coronavirus pandemic are still raw.”

This report stresses the urgency for global collaboration and preparedness to combat these emerging health threats.

item.title: 10 Indian fruits that are red in colour - The Times of India
item.description: No summary available for this article. Click the link to read more.

item.title: Cases Of Norovirus Surge Across The United States: CDC Data Shows - TheHealthSite
item.description:
Norovirus Cases Surge Across the US According to CDC

Publication Date: December 2024

Source: The Health Site

The US is experiencing a notable increase in norovirus cases, as reported by the CDC. Recent figures show a significant spike in outbreaks, particularly this winter.

  • There have been 91 reported outbreaks of norovirus, an increase from 69 in late November.
  • Norovirus is the leading cause of diarrhea and vomiting in the US, impacting all age groups.
  • Common symptoms of norovirus include diarrhea, vomiting, nausea, and stomach pain, typically seen within 12 to 48 hours post-exposure.
  • Proper hygiene and handwashing are essential in preventing the spread of norovirus.
  • Annual outbreaks average around 2,500 cases, predominantly occurring in colder months (November to April).
"Most people with norovirus recover within 1 to 3 days, and there is no specific medicine for it. Consult with your healthcare provider if you notice symptoms."

This surge in norovirus infections underscores the importance of public awareness and hygiene to combat the spread of this highly contagious virus.

item.title: Man shares symptoms he faced that led him to being diagnosed with stage four cancer aged 21 - LADbible
item.description:
21-Year-Old Man Diagnosed with Stage Four Cancer Shares His Symptoms

Publication Date: October 2023, Source: LADbible

A young man from Sydney, Jay Shew, shares his experiences leading to a late-stage diagnosis of Hodgkin’s lymphoma. His story serves as a crucial reminder for others to recognize and act upon health warning signs.

  • Jay was diagnosed with stage four Hodgkin's lymphoma at age 21.
  • He initially dismissed symptoms like high calcium levels and significant weight loss.
  • Family and friends noticed changes in his appearance before he did.
  • He later experienced severe back pain, night sweats, and tireless fatigue.
  • Jay underwent a blood test that led to further investigations, revealing his diagnosis.
  • He is now in recovery and actively sharing his story to inform others about cancer symptoms.
“I’m glad I’m better now and at the moment, I'm just trying my best to maintain good health and of course convince other people to get themselves checked up before it’s too late,”

Jay aims to raise awareness about the importance of early detection in cancer treatment.

item.title: Substance use in teens leads to altered brain structure: US study - Deccan Herald
item.description:
Substance use in teens leads to altered brain structure: US study

Published: 31 December 2024, Source: Deccan Herald

This study conducted by researchers from Washington University in St. Louis highlights significant differences in brain structures of teenagers who engage in substance use, including alcohol and cannabis, compared to those who do not.

  • The study discovered that some brain differences are possibly present before the initiation of substance use.
  • The prefrontal cortex, crucial for decision-making and planning, showed notable variations influenced by substance use.
  • Unique brain differences were identified based on the type of substance used.
  • The research analyzed MRI scans of 9,804 children over three years.
  • Findings were published in The Journal of the American Medical Association (JAMA) Network Open.
“This study adds to some emerging evidence that an individual's brain structure, alongside their unique genetics, environmental exposures and interactions among these factors, may impact their level of risk and resilience for substance use and addiction.” - Nora Volkow, Director of the National Institute on Drug Abuse

Overall, this study aims to further understand the interplay of genetic, environmental, and structural factors influencing substance use among adolescents.

item.title: Winter health heroes: Indian superfoods to keep you warm and energised - Media India Group
item.description: No summary available for this article. Click the link to read more.
